abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A special kind of window that typically performs a function that is auxiliary to the main window.
A window that an app displays on the screen.
Constants that specify the style of a window, and that you can combine with the C bitwise OR operator.
The window displays none of the usual peripheral elements. Useful only for display or caching purposes. A window that uses
can’t become key or main, unless the value of
or
is
. Note that you can set a window’s or panel’s style mask to
in Interface Builder by deselecting Title Bar in the Appearance section of the Attributes inspector.
The window displays a close button.
The window is a document-modal panel (or  a subclass of
The window can appear full screen. A fullscreen window does not draw its title bar, and may have special handling for its toolbar. (This mask is automatically toggled when
is called.)
When set, the window’s

consumes the full size of the window. Although you can combine this constant with other window style masks, it is respected only for windows with a title bar. Note that using this mask opts in to layer-backing. Use the
or the
to lay out views underneath the title bar–toolbar area.
The window is a HUD panel.
The window displays a minimize button.
The window is a panel or a subclass of
that does not activate the owning app.
The window can be resized by the user.
The window uses a textured background that darkens when the window is key or main and lightens when it is inactive, and may have a second gradient in the section below the window content.
The window displays a title bar.
This constant has no effect, because all windows that include a toolbar use the unified style.

A Boolean value that indicates whether the window can become the key window.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the window can become the application’s main window.
A value used by Auto Layout constraints to automatically bind to the value of
The area inside the window that is for non-obscured content, in window coordinates.
The window’s content view, the highest accessible view object in the window’s view hierarchy.
Takes the window into or out of fullscreen mode,
A true value.
